column2: RIM’s BlackBerry Dethroned by Apple on Its Home Turf
column3: Research In Motion can’t say “There’s no place like home” anymore. The BlackBerry maker is losing adoring fans in its own territory, Canada, to Apple’s iPhone.

column2: Apple’s Havens: A World of Subsidiaries
column3: A collection of documents from the company’s overseas units sheds light on how they fit together.

column2: How Apple Sidesteps Billions in Taxes
column3: Apple serves as a window on how technology giants have taken advantage of tax codes written for an industrial age and ill suited to today’s digital economy.

column2: Apple’s Response on Its Tax Practices
column3: A statement from the company in response to an investigation by The New York Times.

column2: Apple Profit Rises on Higher iPhone and iPad Sales
column3: Sales in China helped lift overall iPhone sales by 88 percent over the same quarter a year ago, dispelling fears that sales would lag in nations with lower annual incomes.

column2: Daily Report: Apple’s Profit Rises on iPhone Sales
column3: Apple released its quarterly earnings on Tuesday, and as Nick Wingfield reports in Wednesday’s New York Times, it was yet another blockbuster period. The company nearly doubled its profit from the year-ago quarter, buoyed largely by sales of the iPhone, especially in China.

column2: Former Apple Executive Blends Genres with iPad
column3: Jean-Marie Hullot, a computer scientist and a longtime associate of Steve Jobs at Apple and NeXT, is one of the latest people to use the iPad to blend genres through a start-up he founded called Fotopedia. The company has started to attract a following with its own growing catalog of apps that seek to combine the elegance of photo-rich coffee table books with some of the utility of travel guides.

column2: Greenpeace Protests Apple’s Energy Practices By Releasing Balloons
column3: Members of Greenpeace, the environmental advocacy group, released balloons in the Apple store on Fifth Avenue to call attention to the company’s use of coal power at its facilities.

column2: Tim Cook Spells Out the Rapid Growth of Apple’s iPad
column3: The iPad has been nothing less than a phenomenon, though many Wall Street analysts seem to miss that point. In just two years Apple has sold 67 million iPads. It took Apple 24 years to sell as many Macs, five years to sell as many iPods and over three years to sell as many iPhones.

column2: Parents’ Fight With Apple Over ‘Bait Apps’ Moves Forward
column3: Is Apple doing enough to protect parents’ wallets from their own children? That seems to be the debate that has been brewing in a year-old lawsuit related to iPhone apps and the purchasing mechanisms inside them. After parents type in their password to the App Store, children have a window to keep buying stuff.

column2: Apple Not Likely to Be a Loser in the E-Book Legal Fight
column3: If Apple loses the legal case filed against it and book publishers on Wednesday over e-book pricing, will it be deeply wounded in its growing rivalry with Amazon? Not likely, analysts say. If e-book prices plummet as a result of the lawsuit — one possible outcome — chances are the financial impact on Apple will be small.

column2: Fiona Apple Faces Outward
column3: Her songs have built Fiona Apple, whose new album is partly titled “The Idler Wheel,” an audience that follows her intently, with both admiration and concern.

column2: Facebook vs. Apple
column3: Relations between Facebook and Apple are a bit like those between the United States and China. The two companies, great powers in their own right, are neither friends, nor outright hostile toward each other.

column2: Apple’s Tim Cook on Steve Jobs, Leadership and Manufacturing
column3: Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, took the stage at a tech conference and said very little. But the audience listened anyway for the clues in what he didn’t say about product plans. But Mr. Cook did speak more candidly about his relationship with Steve Jobs and about his approach to succeeding the Apple co-founder as chief executive.

column2: Apple Strikes Back at Government E-Book Lawsuit
column3: The gist of Apple’s is the same as its previous comments on the case. The company denies that it conspired with book publishers to raise e-book prices in a bid to give Apple’s new iPad a boost and to thwart the low e-book pricing of Amazon. But Apple put its objections to the case in somewhat sharper terms in the new filing.

column2: Kodak Loses Patent Case Against Apple and RIM
column3: A judge said that RIM and Apple had not violated Kodak’s patent for digital image-preview technology, because the patent was invalid.

column2: Head of Time Warner Cable Is Unfamiliar With Apple’s AirPlay
column3: AirPlay, a software tool included with Apple’s iPads and iPhones, is widely viewed as being potentially disruptive to the cable industry, because it makes it easy for people to view a broad variety of Internet content on a television. Time Warner Cable’s leader, however, hasn’t heard of it.

column2: Apple Updates iOS 5.1
column3: A new release of Apple’s operating system for mobile devices and tablets, iOS 5.1.1, addresses some bugs found in the previous version.

column2: Facebook Tries, Tries Again on a Smartphone
column3: Can a software company build its own smartphone? We may well find out soon. This past week, Google completed its acquisition of the hardware maker Motorola Mobility for $12.5 billion, which could lead to the search giant’s making its own smartphone. But another software titan might be getting into the hardware game as well: Facebook.

column2: Steve Jobs Still Looms Large
column3: Steven P. Jobs died nearly eight months ago, but the technology industry is not ready to let him go. At a technology conference where he frequently spoke, his close friends — and those whose lives intersected with his — spoke of him fondly.

column2: An App for Art Lovers
column3: The artwork-collection app artCircles belongs on every art lover’s iPad, but owners of the third-generation tablet can have even more fun with the app than others.

column2: Business Day Live | Apple Stores
column3: June 25, 2012 - David Segal on Apple's retail army.

column2: Flipboard, Another Apple Darling, Expands to Android
column3: Yet another app that was exclusive to Apple’s mobile devices is expanding to Google’s Android platform and elsewhere. What’s unusual about the company behind this app, Flipboard, is that it was co-founded by a former Apple employee who worked on the iPhone.

column2: Apple’s Retail Army, Long on Loyalty but Short on Pay
column3: While consumers tend to think of Apple’s headquarters as the company’s heart and soul, a majority of its workers in the United States are hourly wage earners selling iPhones and MacBooks.

column2: Apple’s Maps Don’t Look So Bad
column3: Side-by-side comparisons of Apple’s mobile map and Google maps have been moving around the Internet, and Apple’s map looks terribly light on information by contrast. That is not the final product, though. Apple skinned data off the maps it showed developers. The question is, why?

column2: Pondering the Rest of the Apple Announcements
column3: In its keynote at the Worldwide Developers Conference in San Francisco, Apple took the wraps off enough new features and products to cover a mummy parade. Here are some further reflections on the MacBook Air, iOS 6 and Mountain Lion.

column2: Apple Tweaks Its ‘We’re Safe’ Message and Antivirus Makers Take Notice
column3: Apple, which once bragged that that its Mac computer “Doesn’t get PC viruses,” recently tweaked its marketing message to read: “Built to be safe.” Antivirus makers have been quick to call the tweak an official admission by Apple that this computers are no longer immune from attacks common to PCs running Windows. Or is it just the latest instance of antivirus makers over-hyping a threat to sell more product because Apple is selling significantly more computers than ever before?

column2: Q&A: Changing Your Apple ID E-Mail Address
column3: If you have changed e-mail addresses since you signed up for an iTunes account, you can easily switch it to your new address — most of the time.

column2: Is Apple Splitting the Baby?
column3: Apple’s new Next Generation MacBook Pro adds a powerful new laptop to the company’s product line, but that addition also makes the company’s product line a little more confusing. Apple’s MacBook Pro line requires more parsing on the part of the consumer today than it did yesterday.

column2: Apple Updates Laptops and Mobile Software
column3: The company’s high-end laptop computer, the MacBook Pro, will have a high-resolution “retina display” like the one on the screens of new iPads and iPhones.

column2: ‘Top Gear,’ Stig-less on Apple’s Screens
column3: The BBC has introduced a series of video-game challenges for play on Apple devices, but it lacks some familiar, and beloved, personalities.

column2: The Payout in an Apple Upgrade
column3: Apple offers Mountain Lion, a new version of its OS X software for the Mac. With “over 200 new features,” it costs $20, but is it worth it?

column2: Suggestions for an Apple Shopping List
column3: Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has a cash supply of $117 billion. That could buy a lot of useful technology.

column2: Softer Sales of iPhones Hurt Apple
column3: Apple sold 28 percent more iPhones last quarter than it did a year earlier, but the growth failed to meet the lofty expectations of analysts.

column2: Apple to Acquire AuthenTec for $356 Million
column3: The acquisition of the company, which designs security products for mobile devices such as fingerprint sensors, could help Apple bolster the security of its products,

column2: Apple-Samsung Patent Battle Shifts to Trial
column3: A trial opening Monday is the latest phase in a global campaign of smartphone patent litigation whose importance goes beyond legal maneuvering.

column2: Apple Officials Said to Consider Stake in Twitter
column3: Apple, which has stumbled in its efforts to get into social media, has talked with Twitter in recent months about making a strategic investment in it, according to people briefed on the matter.

column2: Apple Files Another Wearable Computing Patent
column3: Apple’s latest patent filing looks like it is for a bold new fashion statement, but it is for another in the company’s line of wearable computing patents.

column2: Apple’s New iPhone Is Said to Be Set for September Debut
column3: Apple is said to be ready to introduce a new iPhone with an event on Sept. 12, according to a person with knowledge of Apple’s plans.

column2: One of Apple’s Best Ideas Ever — Made Worse
column3: They are not infallible design geniuses at Apple. Its MagSafe connector used to be a design marvel and a joy to use. Then Apple made it worse. It’s now annoying and useless.

column2: TimesCast Tech: Apple’s Earnings and Mountain Lion
column3: Apple announces earnings and introduces Mountain Lion, online education goes to camp and a company brings children’s voices to its apps.

column2: Tokyo Court Hands Win to Samsung Over Apple
column3: A Tokyo court ruled Friday that Samsung’s mobile products did not infringe on Apple’s patents.

column2: Samsung Case Puts Apple Closer to Google Fight
column3: By making its own hardware, Google could end up more squarely in Apple’s sights. The jury’s findings in the case could potentially force Google to adjust its software, too.

column2: Apple Case Muddies the Future of Innovations
column3: For companies that emphasize distinctive design, the Samsung patent verdict was a validation of their efforts.

column2: Business Day Live | Apple's Victory
column3: August 28, 2012 - Apple sets the stage for a war with Google.

column2: Apple Rejects App Tracking Drone Strikes
column3: Apple has rejected an iPhone app that puts United States drone strikes on an interactive map because it ran afoul of Apple rules on objectionable content. But a similar map was published earlier this month through the iPhone app for The Guardian, the British newspaper.

column2: Apple Beats Samsung: First Reactions
column3: Here’s some early reaction to Apple’s sweeping victory over Samsung Electronics in its patent dispute.

column2: Jury Awards $1 Billion to Apple in Samsung Patent Case
column3: The jury found that Samsung infringed upon a series of Apple patents on mobile devices, in a closely watched court case that could have broad implications for the industry.

column2: Apple Seeks Order Blocking Sale of Samsung Products
column3: Apple asked a federal judge to block the sale of more than a half dozen Samsung smartphones, after a jury found that Samsung had infringed a series of Apple’s mobile patents.

column2: Business Day Live: Facebook and Apple
column3: The Times’s daily business show looks at whether Facebook has lost credibility with Wall Street and the remarkable transformation of Apple.

column2: Secrets Learned in Apple-Samsung Trial
column3: The problem when companies go to trial is that the public gets to hear corporate secrets.

column2: Apple Apologizes for Misstep on Maps
column3: The problems with Apple’s new mobile maps were embarrassing, but the company has a tendency to bungle services that rely heavily on the Internet.

column2: Has Apple Peaked?
column3: The nasty glitch in the iPhone 5 suggests that the law of big companies even applies to the most valuable one in America.

column2: Tim Cook Apologizes for Apple’s Maps
column3: Complaints and jokes about Apple’s new maps have not stopped since the company released iOS 6 last week, a software update that replaced Google’s maps with its own. Now the company’s chief executive, Tim Cook, is apologizing.

column2: Apple’s Competitors Pile On With Map Critiques
column3: Google said it hasn’t made a move to restore its maps to the iPhone, but it declined to say whether the company had submitted a new maps app to Apple’s App Store. And why would Google show its cards? Here is an opportunity for the company to show that phones using Android have a more robust maps product. Some of Apple’s other competitors are already playing this game.

column2: Apple’s Feud With Google Is Now Felt on iPhone
column3: Once the best of friends, Google and Apple are battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace, with iPhone users in the cross-fire after Apple removed Google’s maps app and YouTube.

column2: Japanese Look for Alternatives to Apple’s Maps
column3: Alternative mapping companies in Japan, like Navitime, are using the opportunity of Apple’s less-than-stellar iPhone maps to trumpet their wares.

column2: As Apple’s Maps Stumbles, AOL’s MapQuest Flourishes
column3: Apple’s map application debacle has been a boon for an unlikely suspect: MapQuest. The map company, owned by AOL, seemed to have been eclipsed in the era of in-car GPS and smartphones, but it is experiencing a resurgence.

column2: Poking Fun at Apple’s New Maps
column3: Now that plenty of iPhone customers have had a chance to use the new Apple maps for a few days, the reactions have been strong, and often sarcastic.

column2: Apple Sells Five Million New iPhones
column3: Apple on Monday said it had sold 5 million new iPhones just three days after the phone’s release, beating first-weekend sales of its predecessor, the iPhone 4S, by about one million, but still missing some analysts’ forecasts. Still, the number sold over the weekend is about as many smartphones as some competitors, like Nokia, can say they’ve sold over all.

column2: Samsung-Apple Fight Moves to Marketing
column3: Samsung’s campaign takes on the iPhone 5 directly, claiming its new Galaxy phone is better.

column2: Big Apple Circus
column3: “Legendarium” comes to Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center.

column2: Daily Report: A Shake-Up at Apple
column3: Even as Hurricane Sandy pounded the East Coast, the ouster of Scott Forstall at Apple roiled the tech world.

column2: Apple Takes On Smaller Tablets
column3: TimesCast Media+Tech: Apple reveals the iPad Mini. | David Pogue reviews the Microsoft Surface in 60 seconds. | The Mr. GIF artist collective.

column2: In Shake-Up, Apple’s Mobile Software and Retail Chiefs to Depart
column3: Scott Forstall, who has run software development for Apple’s iPad and iPhone products, and John Browett, the head of the company’s retail operations, are leaving Apple, in a rare management reshuffling at the company.

column2: Apple Profit Rises 24% on Sales of iPhone 5
column3: Apple’s profits were buoyed by sales of its new iPhone, which was introduced nine days before the quarter’s end.

column2: Apple, Facing Competition, Introduces a Smaller iPad
column3: With a 7.9-inch screen, Apple’s new device is smaller and lighter than the regular iPad. But at $330, it costs about $130 more than similarly sized tablets from competitors.

column2: Updates From Apple’s Product Event
column3: Apple unveiled a smaller iPad, a new iMac and other revamped products at an event at the California Theater in San Jose, Calif.

column2: Disruptions: You Know You Can’t Live Without Apple’s Latest Glass Rectangle
column3: Each new Apple product makes the previous generation look old. How else could the company persuade people into replacing their perfectly fine iPhones, iPads and iPods year after year?

column2: Digital Notes: Apple Delays Latest iTunes Upgrade
column3: The upgrade, said to be the most significant in the 11-year life of the program, was supposed to come in October. Now the plan is November, Apple says, so it can “get it right.”

column2: TimesCast Media + Tech: Apple’s Smaller Tablets
column3: Apple reveals the iPad Mini. David Pogue reviews the Microsoft Surface in 60 seconds. The Mr. GIF artist collective.

column2: Apple and Google’s Tax on Developers
column3: When two rich and powerful companies go head to head trying to attract talent, the weapon of choice is usually money. Yet even as Apple and Google strive for dominance in apps, neither seems to be doing much to woo developers.

column2: Apple and the Desire for Control
column3: Apple is the first, last and only word on which apps are allowed on its array of mobile devices. It is a system that has worked out very well for Apple, its customers and some developers. At what point does it become something to worry about?

column2: Apple Fires a Manager Over Its Misfire on Maps
column3: Apple continues to clean house after it stumbled badly with its mobile mapping service, firing a manager who oversaw it. Eddy Cue, the senior vice president for Internet software and services at Apple, fired the manager, Richard Williamson, according to two people briefed on the matter.

column2: Fiona Apple Postpones Tour to Care for Dying Dog
column3: The singer said she will delay a tour to South American cities because she cannot leave her dying dog behind.

column2: Apple Now Owns the Page Turn
column3: Apple was granted a design patent this week for the page turn in an e-reader application. This is not from The Onion.

column2: Parallel Exits at Microsoft and Apple
column3: TimesCast Media+Tech: The abrupt departure of Microsoft’s Steven Sinofsky. | David Pogue reviews fitness bands in 60 seconds. | Integrating technology into the way children play.

column2: The Breakfast Meeting: Managing the Petraeus Scandal, and Fiona Apple’s Loyalty to Her Dog
column3: Also, Kevin Clash, the puppeteer and voice behind Elmo on “Sesame Street,” resigns after a new allegation that he had an underage sexual relationship.

column2: Apple Maps Find Appalachia in Manhattan
column3: Metropolitan Diary: An iPhone user describes some horrors when trying to use Apple’s new map application for a Manhattan address.

column2: As Apple’s Battle With HTC Ends, Smartphone Patent Fights Continue
column3: Apple’s settlement of an Android-related lawsuit could be a sign that its chief wants to end the distraction of patent fights, but it does not necessarily portend a similar agreement with Samsung.

column2: Product Questions and Threats of Higher Tax Hit Apple Shares
column3: Shares have dropped 20 percent since their September peak. Some investors may be selling in anticipation of higher capital gains taxes.

column2: Q&A: How to Share an Apple TV
column3: The Apple TV set-top box can work with multiple iTunes accounts, as long as you have a recent Apple TV hardware and updated software for it.

column2: Revisiting Apple, NBC and Gay Marriage
column3: As 2013 approaches, an update on some topics from 2012: the success of “The Voice,” a North Carolina businessman’s stand for gay marriage and whither Apple?

column2: Apple’s Statement on Factory Conditions in China
column3: The company said it has “sought help from the world’s leading experts, and established groundbreaking educational programs for workers.”

column2: Some Subway Arrival Times Are Now Just an Apple Device Away
column3: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority unveiled the app to provide real-time information for six of the system’s numbered lines and the 42nd Street shuttle.

column2: U.S. Office Rejects 2nd Apple Patent
column3: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has declared that one of the patents that helped Apple win $1.05 billion in damages against Samsung should not have been granted.

column2: A Pay Cut for Tim Cook? Not Really
column3: Apple filed documents with regulators revealing that its chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, took what might look like a significant pay cut in 2012. But the giant stock package Mr. Cook received last year will vest over 10 years.

column2: Samsung Ends Its Push for a European Sales Ban on Some Apple Products
column3: Samsung had been seeking injunctions in a number of countries, contending that Apple had infringed on its patents. Pressure from Europe may have contributed to the decision.

column2: While Apple Regroups, Google Offers a Maps App
column3: The release of a new Google Maps app for the iPhone may help Apple customers find their way, but it will not relieve Apple of the pressure to improve its own service.

column2: Does Apple’s Tim Cook Want an Apple Television?
column3: In an interview with NBC, the chief executive of Apple, Timothy D. Cook, said the television was “an area of intense interest” for the company. Apple has been trying to make its way into the living room since 2006, when it announced the Apple TV set-top box.

column2: Assessing Apple's Grand Statement
column3: Deputy Editor David Gillen leads a roundtable discussion on whether Apple's promise to expand manufacturing in the U.S. will turn out to be good news for American workers.

column2: For Investors, Apple Not as Shiny
column3: The Times's Nick Wingfield talks about Apple's detrimental legacy of success.

column2: Video: For Investors, Apple Not as Shiny
column3: The Times’s Nick Wingfield talks about Apple’s detrimental legacy of success.

column2: Apple May Be Big, but It Isn’t a Bellwether
column3: In good times and bad, Apple’s stock has often gone its own way. But shares of I.B.M., whose market value isn’t as high, still appear to have more influence on the overall market.

column2: Does Apple Need a Cheaper iPhone?
column3: In the past month, there have been reports that Apple is working on a smaller, cheaper iPhone. But the latest sales numbers do not make it appear that Apple needs to sell one.

column2: Apple Takes Aim at Providers of Underage Laborers
column3: Labor recruiters in China last year knowingly provided underage workers to a supplier that built parts for products from Apple and other companies. That finding was included in Apple’s 2013 report on labor conditions at its suppliers, where more than 1.5 million workers make or assemble the ingredients that go into its products.

column2: Heady Returns, but Apple Finds Its Stock Falling
column3: Investors have come to expect nothing short of perfection from Apple, but with the company’s stock sinking 11 percent, it is clear there are a range of challenges.

column2: TSMC Anticipates Big Orders. Is Apple One of Them?
column3: The chief executive of TSMC, one of the biggest semiconductor makers in the world, hinted at big orders to come, fueling the Apple rumor mill that the iPhone maker may soon shift its chip production to the Taiwanese company.

column2: Digital Notes: Amazon Enters Apple’s Phones to Compete on Music Downloads
column3: Amazon has stepped up its competition against iTunes with a version of its MP3 store for Apple’s iPhones and iPod Touch devices.

column2: Foxconn Begins Bribery Investigation
column3: The company, which makes the Apple iPhone and other popular products, said it was investigating whether its employees had accepted bribes from supply-chain partners.

column2: The 2012 Patent Rankings: IBM on Top (Again), Google and Apple Surging
column3: The yearly count of corporate patent winners shows I.B.M. on top in 2012, for the 20th consecutive year. But the big movement in the rankings comes from two combatants in the smartphone patent wars, Google and Apple. Both companies had surge of patents granted last year.

column2: Apple Computers Hit by Sophisticated Cyberattack
column3: Apple says its systems were attacked by the same group that hit Twitter and Facebook. Like Facebook, Apple confirmed that its employees’ computers were infected with malware when they visited a Web site for mobile developers.

column2: Judge Sides With Einhorn and Halts an Apple Shareholder Vote
column3: A federal judge on Friday ordered Apple to halt collecting shareholder votes on a contentious proposal to change some of its corporate charter, handing a victory to the hedge fund manager David Einhorn.

column2: In Apple Fight, Einhorn Unveils ‘iPrefs’
column3: Apple has introduced perhaps more innovative consumer products than any other company has over the past decade, including the iPhone. Now, the hedge fund manager David Einhorn wants the company to roll out what he calls iPrefs.

column2: Why Einhorn’s Win May Be Apple’s Gain
column3: David Einhorn’s victory against Apple in Federal District Court in Manhattan – over a shareholder proposal – may be more of a win for the technology giant.

column2: Apple Filed Patent for Flexible Wrist Display
column3: Apple on Thursday filed a patent for a watchlike device that could wrap around someone’s wrist. The gadget comes with a touch screen and can list recent phone calls and text messages.

column2: Court Gives Investor an Edge in a Lawsuit Against Apple
column3: A federal judge says he is leaning toward the hedge fund magnate David Einhorn’s contention in a lawsuit that Apple violated securities regulations by improperly bundling several shareholder proposals into one matter.

column2: Apple Agrees to Settle Lawsuit Over App Purchases by Children
column3: Apple has agreed to reimburse parents whose children purchased virtual goods in mobile apps without the parents’ knowledge. Apple and the plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed against the company in 2011 last week asked a judge to approve a settlement over such unauthorized “in-app purchases.”

column2: How Lightning Tightens Apple’s Control Over Accessories
column3: When the iPhone 5 was released in September with the new Lightning connection port, all those docks and accessories that longtime Apple customers had been collecting for years were suddenly obsolete. But it has taken a long time for new accessories compatible with Lightning to hit the market. Here’s why.

column2: Samsung Emerges as a Potent Rival to Apple’s Cool
column3: After sweeping the market with the iPhone and the iPad, Apple has only one real competitor. And Samsung, unlike Apple, does think people know what they want.

column2: Unusual Moves in Confronting Apple’s Huge Pile of Cash
column3: With $140 billion in cash at stake, Apple and the hedge fund manager David Einhorn have been acting strangely.

column2: Intertrust Sues Apple, Charging Patent Violations
column3: Intertrust, which received a huge patent infringement settlement from Microsoft nearly a decade ago, has turned its focus to Apple with a lawsuit filed on Wednesday.

column2: With Acquisition, Apple Looks Indoors for Future of Maps
column3: Apple has acquired WiFiSlam, a start-up company that helps improve the accuracy of indoor maps and other services. Indoor maps look poised to become a new battleground between big tech companies.

column2: Daily Report: Samsung Invades Apple’s Turf
column3: Increasing the stakes in the smartphone battle, the South Korean manufacturer showed off the Galaxy S IV, the latest version of its flagship device, Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield report on Friday in The New York Times.

column2: Samsung Introduces New Galaxy Phone
column3: Increasing the stakes in the smartphone battle, the South Korean manufacturer showed off the Galaxy S IV, the latest version of its flagship device.

column2: Q&A: Keyboarding With an Apple TV
column3: The Apple TV set-top box can now work with wireless Bluetooth keyboards, but you do not have to use an Apple-branded model.

column2: Apple’s Internet Radio Service Said to Be Delayed
column3: The company’s efforts to create an Internet radio service to compete with Pandora has been delayed by licensing negotiations with music companies, according to a number of people briefed on the talks.

column2: A Highly Public Trip for China’s President, and Its First Lady
column3: China’s leadership has been promoting a concept called the “Chinese Dream” that depends on continued economic growth and stable relations with the United States. Apple, meanwhile, finds itself the target of attacks in the official media.

column2: An Easy Way to Capture Live Video of Your iPhone’s Screen
column3: A $13 program called Reflector transmits the video image from your iPhone, iPod or iPad to your Macintosh or PC for easy recording or projecting. It’s a great help for anyone making videos or trying to conduct a presentation.

column2: How to Unlock That Stashed Foreign Cash
column3: Various American companies have parked huge sums of money abroad.  One money manager says they should repatriate that wealth, pay taxes on it and then watch their stock prices rise.

column2: Judge Cuts Sum Owed to Apple Over Patents
column3: A federal judge lessened the blow from Apple’s legal victory in a patent case over Samsung, lopping more than 40 percent off the damages.

column2: Apple and the Debt Market
column3: With an expanded budget for dividends and stock buybacks, Apple could be on track to borrow nearly $20 billion a year, putting the company in the same issuance ballpark as huge global banks.

column2: The Check Is in the Mail, From Apple
column3: Apple iPhone 4 owners began receiving $15 checks in the mail Tuesday as a result of a class action settled by the company last year.

column2: As Profit Slips, Apple Looks to Reward Shareholders
column3: The technology giant, which reported the first decline in quarterly earnings in a decade, announced plans to spend more than $100 billion on stock buybacks and dividends.

column2: After Apple’s Rise, a Bruising Fall
column3: Shares of Apple were trading for more than $700 last year, but they have tumbled back and analysts are trying to understand why.

column2: Einhorn Supports Apple’s Big Payouts
column3: Apple’s huge gift to investors has at least one big fan: David Einhorn, the prominent hedge fund manager who took on the company over its payouts to shareholders.

column2: Comparing the Valuations Behind Amazon and Apple Shares
column3: Investors seem to be starry-eyed about Amazon’s valuation, particularly when compared with Apple’s.

column2: To Satisfy Its Investors, Cash-Rich Apple Borrows Money
column3: Why would a company with $145 billion in cash even bother to issue debt? The answer has a lot to do with the frenzied state of the bond markets.

column2: Apple’s Buyback Takes a Bite Out of Its Cash Pile, Temporarily
column3: Despite the attention-grabbing numbers, the iPad maker could quickly replace the withdrawal from its cash hoard, which now totals $145 billion.

column2: Daily Report: Apple’s Profits Are Strong but Its Shares Are Skidding
column3: Shares of Apple traded for more than $700 last year, but they have tumbled and analysts are trying to understand why, Nick Wingfield and Nathaniel Popper write in The New York Times.

column2: Apple of Discord in China
column3: There are a number of theories about why official Chinese media outlets are attacking Apple. And while many Chinese commentators online are mocking the state media, the company does appear to have a problem with Beijing.

column2: How Vintage Apple Computers Used to Sell
column3: Original Apple-1 computers can now sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars at professional auctions. But the vintage machines have been selling informally for years. The story of the 1997 sale of an Apple-1, now residing at the Computer History Museum, shows how things worked in simpler times. That Apple-1 was a treasured prize for the young entrepreneur who bought it, and the sale was a financial lifeline for a struggling single mother.

column2: The Corrosive Effect of Apple’s Tax Avoidance
column3: In a Senate subcommittee hearing on Apple’s avoidance of paying taxes, John McCain and others tried to point out how unfair the current system was to domestic corporations.

column2: Apple and Tax Avoidance
column3: Why would Apple executives try to avoid paying billions in taxes in the United States and around the world?

column2: Former E.P.A. Administrator Joins Apple
column3: Lisa P. Jackson, who oversaw some of the administration’s biggest environmental initiatives, will serve as the company’s senior environmental adviser.

column2: The C.E.O. Triumphant (at Least at Apple and Chase)
column3: It was a good week for leaders of two major American companies. But it brought frowns from some corporate-governance watchers.

column2: Vintage Apple-1 Sells for Record $671,400
